bibl.author: Richard Maurice Bucke
bibl.title: Richard Maurice Bucke to Walt Whitman, 26 November 1891
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

revisionDesc.change: Second check: corrected transcription and encoding, added notes

body.p: I am pleased and relieved beyond expression to hear that the "tomb" matter is really in course of settlement on a satisfactory basis—the apparent attempt to swindle if really made was one of the vilest acts I have ever heard of—so vile does it seem to me that I hesitate to believe it without the strongest evidence. I shall hope to hear some of the "ins and outs" of this matter later.—We have got through with our three days' rain and are now having charming weather—we all keep well and hearty here and in good spirits—I wish I could here better accounts from you as to your own state of health
